prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my sister’s boyfriend he’s not “family”?
My sister has been dating this guy for less than three months.  My personal feelings are that he’s an idiot.  I mean he’s young (either late teens or early twenties, idk) so it’s understandable.  I was an idiot back then too.  My problem with him is that he’s made some dangerous choices with my sister involved.  He wrecked his truck with her in it driving drunk.  He also took my sister around this ex felon that everyone in town knows is scary dude just so he could buy some “pot” if it was really pot.  The guy sells a lot more than pot.  He’s definitely not someone I want knowing or getting close with my sister.  

Despite that, it’s her choice who she dates so I’ve kept my opinions to myself until now.  I think he mistook politeness for friendship or something.  He’s shown up at my apartment to hang out.  When I visit my mom’s and he’s there he will basically attache himself to my hip.  Most annoying of all he started calling me brother and fam.  I know those aren’t always specifically referring to actual family, but it’s just what it’s felt like.  

It really got under my skin quickly.  The last time he did it I told him, “You’re not my family.  You’re the guy my sister is dating for now.”   He just said “alright” and I walked away. 

He’s just trying to be friendly and get close with his girlfriend’s family, I understand that.  It felt like it was time for a reality check on our relationship though.  I probably pissed my sister off in the process, I haven’t heard from her since it happened.  



"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the story is in the wrong. The situation is that the author told their sister's boyfriend he's not family. The sister has been dating this guy for under three months. The author has concerns about the boyfriend's behavior—he was drunk driving with her sister, took her to see a scary ex-felon to buy drugs, and the boyfriend was being overly familiar, calling the author "brother" and "fam." The author finally told the boyfriend he's not family, which led to the sister not contacting them since.

So, the main question is whether the author was wrong to say that. Let's break it down. The author's concerns are valid: the boyfriend's actions are dangerous and risky. The author is trying to protect their sister. But the author is not the one in a relationship with him; that's the sister. The author's intervention might have been harsh, but maybe it was necessary to set boundaries. The boyfriend was overstepping by showing up uninvited, being overly familiar, and the author felt it was a reality check. 

However, the author didn't confront the sister first, which might have been a better approach. Telling the boyfriend directly that he's not family could be seen as cutting off a connection the sister might value. But the boyfriend's behavior was concerning, and the author has the right to set boundaries for their own comfort. The sister might be upset because her boyfriend was reprimanded, but the author's actions were protective. 

So, is the author in the wrong? The answer is probably no. The author had legitimate concerns, and setting boundaries is okay. The sister is an adult and can make her own choices, but the author isn't obligated to be friendly with someone they don't trust. The key points are the boyfriend's dangerous behavior and the author's right to distance themselves. So the answer would be B (No).
